text: Approximately 80% of working women in India take career breaks, with 45% citing childcare and personal commitments as primary reasons.
source: Times of India: 'Career breaks tricky for women, salary gap persists, says survey'

text: A study found that women returning to work after a career break due to care responsibilities receive 49% fewer callbacks compared to those without such breaks.
source: Ashoka University: 'Restart: Women, career breaks and employer response'

text: The Mahindra Group launched 'SOAR', a returnship program aimed at reintegrating women who took career breaks into mainstream roles, offering permanent positions, mentorship, and training.
source: Times of India: 'M&M rolls out 'returnship' programme for women'

text: Women's labor force participation rate in India increased from 23.3% in 2017-18 to 41.7% in 2023-24, while the unemployment rate reduced from 5.6% to 3.2%.
source: Press Information Bureau: 'Enhanced Female Workforce Participation in Economic Activity'

text: In 2023, PepsiCo reported a 97% retention rate among over 200 female leaders in its South Division, attributing this success in part to its returnship program.
source: WorkLife.news: 'PepsiCo, IBM share why their 'returnships' work'

text: A study revealed that 34% of women in India leave their jobs due to work-life balance issues, compared to only 4% of men.
source: Deccan Herald: '34% of women leave jobs in India over work-life balance, study finds'

text: Returnship programs in India are often structured as internships lasting three to six months, sometimes without a guarantee of full-time employment, and may have strict eligibility criteria regarding the length of career breaks.
source: The Economic Times: 'India Inc happy to give you a 2nd innings'

text: In India, 43.4% of mothers reported childcare as the primary reason for their non-participation in the labor market, while 38.4% cited household responsibilities.
source: The Wire: 'Mothers and the Labour Market: Why India Needs to Re-Imagine ...'
